div.p: This term that is closely related to and often placed within the Recognitions element belongs conceptually within WRITING RECEPTION . It supplies the name of a particular award or prize given to an author. Generally encloses one or two words, the name of an award, but can enclose more words, e.g. short-listed for or runner-up to. The REG attribute offers a way to chart the changes of name often undergone by awards, like the Bailey’s Prize / the Orange Prize for Women’s Writing. Use the textbase itself to ascertain our practice in each case. This element has no mandatory or optional sub-elements.

When including the fact that a woman writer received a CBE, DBE, or OBE in recognition of her literary achievements, the practice is to use the acronyms for the awards in your prose and spell out their meaning in the attributes as follows: CBE Commander of the Order of the British Empire; DBE Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire; OBE Officer of the Order of the British Empire. Anyone needing further info can go to the textbase itself, or to: http://www.kcl.ac.uk/lhcma/misc/medals.htm.
Although the full recognition names include Most Excellent, as in Dame Commander, Most Excellent Order of the British Empire, we do not need to include that part.

The above designations, CBE, DBE, and OBE, almost always belong in the writing docs. This designation would be discussed in the biography (without the tag) only if it was nothing to do with her writing, but rewarded some other activity.
